fr:title.text: additive functor is faithful iff it reflects exactness

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: additive functor is faithful iff it reflects exactness

fr:mainmatter.html:p: An additive functor is faithful iff it reflects exactness.

This implies that faithful additive functors reflects kernels, cokernels, etc. Note that faithful functors need not preserve kernels or cokernels. This is because we can take the direct sum of a faithful functor with an arbitrary additive functor and the result is still faithful. The second summand can behave badly.

We first prove the forward implication. Given a sequence X \xrightarrow {f} Y \xrightarrow {g} Z whose image under F is exact, by faithfulness F(g \mathbin {\circ } f) = 0 implies g \mathbin {\circ } f = 0. Now we wish to prove the composite \ker g \to Y \to \operatorname {coker} f is zero. We can decompose its image under F as F(\ker g) \to \ker Fg \to FY \to \operatorname {coker} Ff \to F(\operatorname {coker} f). But the inner two morphisms compose to zero, so by faithfulness we get our result.

On the other hand, suppose F reflects exactness. Given a morphism f : X \to Y, suppose Ff = 0, then FX \xrightarrow {\textrm {id}} FX \xrightarrow {Ff} FY is exact. Hence X \xrightarrow {\textrm {id}} X \xrightarrow {f} Y is also exact, so f = 0 too.
Given two additive categories and a functor F : \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {D} between them, the following are equivalent. In this case, we call the functor additive.

html:ul.html:li: The functor is a homomorphism on the abelian groups \hom _{\mathcal {C}}(X, Y), i.e. it is an \mathsf {Ab}-enriched functor.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the equivalence of the first two claims, we have a composition F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel {\sim \,}{\to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y), where the middle morphism comes from the canonical isomorphism X + Y \stackrel {\sim \,}{\to } F(X \times Y). The first two claim is equivalent to the right and left arrows being iso, respectively. Recall that a morphism from a coproduct to a product is determined by a matrix of morphisms. With this fact and the functoriality of F, we can compute that the composition is the canonical isomorphism from F(X) + F(Y) to F(X) \times F(Y). Therefore the leftmost arrow being iso is equivalent to the rightmost arrow being iso.

Since the abelian group structure on morphisms is uniquely determined from the finite products and coproducts in an additive category, a functor satisfying the first two conditions automatically satisfies the third. Conversely, we need to prove the canonical maps F(1) \to 1 and F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y) are isomorphisms. For the first one, since 1 is also the initial object, any morphism into it is automatically iso. For the second one, we again look at the diagram which composes to an isomorphism: F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel {\sim \,}{\to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y). Using the bilinearity of composition and that F preserves addition on morphisms, we can verify that this provides a two-sided inverse.
